article.title: Crux
article.paragraph: CruxIPAc-enˈkrʌksis a constellation located in the southern sky in a bright portion of theMilky Way, and is theList of constellations by areasmallestbut one of the most distinctive of the 88 modernconstellations. Its name isLatinforcross, and it is dominated by a cross-shaped or kite-likeAsterism (astronomy)asterismthat is commonly known as theSouthern Cross.

Predominating the asterism is the most southerly and brightest starthe blue-whiteAlpha Crucisor Acruxfollowed by four other stars, descending in clockwise order by magnitude:Beta CrucisBeta,Gamma CrucisGamma(one of the closestred giantsto Earth),Delta CrucisDeltaandEpsilon CrucisEpsilonCrucis. Many of these brighter stars are members of theScorpiusCentaurus Association, a large but loose group of hot blue-white stars that appear to share common origins and motion across the southernMilky Way. Two star systems have been found to have planets. The constellation also contains fourClassical Cepheid variableCepheid variablesvisible to the naked eye under optimum conditions. Crux also contains the bright and colourfulopen clusterknownJewel Box (star cluster)Jewel Box(NGC 4755), and to the southwest, the extensivedark nebulaknown as theCoalsack Nebula.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: Crux was known to theAncient Greeksdue to the fact that it can be seen from southern Egypt;Ptolemy, who regarded it as part of the constellation Centaurus.Pasachoff,''Stars and Planets'', 2006, p. 144.sfnStaal1988247It was entirely visible as far north as Britain in the fourth millennium BC. However, theprecession of the equinoxesgradually lowered its stars below the European horizon, and they were eventually forgotten by the inhabitants of northern latitudes.sfnRidpathTirion2001132-133By AD 400, most of the constellation never rose above the horizon for Athenians.Citation neededDecember 2010

link.part: Depiction of the Crux byJoo Farasin May, 1500

article.paragraph: The 15th-century Venetian navigatorAlvise Cadamostomade note of what was probably the Southern Cross on exiting theGambia Riverin 1455, calling it thecarro dell'ostro("southern chariot"). However, Cadamosto's accompanying diagram was inaccurate."We likewise observed...due south by compass, a constellation of six large bright stars, in the figure of a cross in this form...we conjectured this to be the southern chariot, but could not expect to observe the principal star, as we had not yet lost sight of the north pole." A. CadamostoNavigatione, written c.1465 (1550 Ramusio edition,p.116r; 1811 Kerr editionp.244). However, note a the manuscript of Cadamosto's notebook has not survived, only the printed version, and the errors in the diagram may be due to the printer's decision.Dekker, Elly (1990).Annals of Science, vol. 47, pp. 530533.Historians generally creditJoo Faras- astronomer and physician of KingManuel I of Portugalwho accompaniedPedro lvares Cabralin the discovery of Brazil in 1500 - for being the first European to depict it correctly. Faras sketched and described the constellation (calling it "Las Guardas") in a letter written on the beaches of Brazil on May 1, 1500, to the Portuguese monarch.citationRevista do Instituto Histórico e Geográfico BrasileiroRio de Janeiro1843V nº 19.http://books.google.com/books?idDekker, Elly (1990).Annals of Science, vol. 47, pp. 533535.

ExplorerAmerigo Vespucciseems to have observed not only the Southern Cross but also the neighboring Coalsack Nebula on his second voyage in 150102.Dekker, Elly (1990).Annals of Science, vol. 47, pp. 535543.

Another early modern description clearly describing Crux as a separate constellation is attributed toAndrea CorsaliAndreas Corsali, an Italian navigator who from 1515 to 1517 sailed to China and the East Indies in an expedition sponsored by King Manuel I. In 1516, Corsali wrote a letter to the monarch describing his observations of the southern sky, which included a rather crude map of the stars around the south celestial pole including the Southern Cross and the two Magellanic Clouds seen in an external orientation, as on a globe.Dekker, Elly (1990).Annals of Science, vol. 47, pp. 545548.

Emery MolyneuxandPetrus Planciushave also been cited as the first uranographers to distinguish Crux as a separate constellation; their representations date from 1592, the former depicting it on his celestial globe and the latter in one of the small celestial maps on his large wall map. Both authors, however, depended on unreliable sources and placed Crux in the wrong position. Crux was first shown in its correct position on the celestial globes ofPetrus PlanciusandJodocus Hondiusin 1598 and 1600. Its stars were first catalogued separately from Centaurus byFrederick de Houtmanin 1603.cite webhttp://www.ianridpath.com/startales/crux.htmIan Ridpath’s Star Tales – CruxAugust 5, 2013Later adopters of the constellation includedJakob Bartschin 1624 andAugustin Royerin 1679. Royer is sometimes wrongly cited as initially distinguishing Crux.sfnStaal1988247
article.heading: Characteristics
article.paragraph: Crux is bordered by the constellationsCentaurus(which surrounds it on three sides) on the east, north and west, andMuscato the south. Covering 68 square degrees and 0.165% of the night sky, it is the smallest of the 88 constellations.cite bookBagnallPhilip M.The Star Atlas Companion: What You Need to Know about the ConstellationsSpringerNew York, New York2012978-1-4614-0830-7183–87http://books.google.com.au/books?idThe three-letter abbreviation for the constellation, as adopted by theInternational Astronomical Unionin 1922, is 'Cru'.cite journalRussellHenry NorrisHenry Norris RussellThe New International Symbols for the ConstellationsPopular Astronomy304691922PA.....30..469R1922The official constellation boundaries, as set byEugne Joseph DelporteEugne Delportein 1930, are defined by a polygon of four segments. In theequatorial coordinate system, theright ascensioncoordinates of these borders lie betweenRA1156.13andRA1257.45, while thedeclinationcoordinates are between 55.68 and 64.70.Cite journalCrux, Constellation BoundaryThe ConstellationsInternational Astronomical Unionhttp://www.iau.org/public/constellations/#cru23 June 2014The whole constellation is visible to observers south of latitude 25N.cite webhttp://www.ianridpath.com/constellations1.htmConstellations: Andromeda–IndusStar Tales[[Ian Ridpath]]self-published23 June 2014efnWhile parts of the constellation technically rise above the horizon to observers between 25°N and 34°N, stars within a few degrees of the horizon are to all intents and purposes unobservable.<ref name

In tropical regions Crux can be seen in the sky from April to June. Crux is exactly opposite toCassiopeia (constellation)Cassiopeiaon the celestial sphere, and therefore it cannot appear in the sky with the latter at the same time. For locations south of 34S, Crux is circumpolar and thus always visible in the night sky.

Crux is sometimes confused with the nearbyVela (constellation)#False CrossFalse Crossby stargazers. Crux is somewhatkite (geometry)kite-shaped (aLatin cross), and it has a fifth star (Epsilon CrucisCrucis). The False Cross isdiamond-shaped (aGreek cross), somewhat dimmer on average, does not have a fifth star and lacks the two prominent nearby "Pointer Stars."
article.heading: Visibility
article.paragraph: Image:Crux (Southern Cross) from Hobart, Tasmania.jpgthumbleft250pxThe five brightest stars in Crux are clearly visible in the top right. Thered giantGacruxand orange giantEpsilon CrucisEpsilonare distinctly different from the three other major stars of the constellation, which are blue-white in colour.Image:Ctx crux.gifthumb250pxleftACTX (camera)CTXimage of Crux.File:Deep Crux wide field with fog.jpgthumbDeep exposure of Crux,Coalsack Nebula, andIC 2944File:Crux-20100220.jpgthumbrightStacked image of six identical frames of Crux.Crux is easily visible from thesouthern hemisphereat practically any time of year. It is also visible near the horizon fromTropicstropical latitudesof thenorthern hemispherefor a few hours every night during the northern winter and spring. For instance, it is visible fromCancunor any other place at latitude 25 N or less at around 10 pm at the end of April.cite bookField Guide to the Stars and PlanetsPasachoff, Jay M2000Houghton Miflin978-0-395-93431-967cite webhttp://www.ianridpath.com/constellations1.htmIan Ridpath.com: Constellations2015-09-29There are 5 main stars.Due toprecession, Crux will move closer to the South Pole in the next millennia, up to 67 degrees south declination for the middle of the constellation. But in AD 18000 or BC 8000 Crux will be/was less than 30 degrees south declination making it visible in Northern Europe. Even in AD 14000 it will be visible for most parts of Europe and the whole United States.
article.heading: Use in navigation
article.paragraph: Image:Pole01-eng.jpgthumbright400pxLocating the south celestial poleIn theSouthern Hemisphere, the Southern Cross is frequently used for navigation in much the same way that thePolarisis used in theNorthern Hemisphere. Alpha and Gamma (known asAcruxandGacruxrespectively) are commonly used to mark south. Tracing a line from Gacrux to Acrux leads to a point close to the Southern Celestial Pole.sfnRidpathTirion2001132-133Alternatively, if a line is constructed perpendicularly betweenAlpha CentauriandBeta Centauri, the point where the above-mentioned line and this line intersect marks the Southern Celestial Pole. Another way to find south, strike line through Gacrux and Acrux, 3 1/2 times the distance between Gacrux and Acrux, directly below that point is south. The two stars of Alpha and Beta Centauri are often referred to as the "Southern Pointers" or just "The Pointers", allowing people to easily find the asterism of the Southern Cross or the constellation of Crux. Very few bright stars of importance lie between Crux and the pole itself, although the constellationMuscais fairly easily recognised immediately beneath Crux.

A technique used in the field is to clench one's right fist and to view the cross, aligning the first knuckle with the axis of the cross. The tip of the thumb will indicate south.cite bookDon't die in the Bundu DH Grainger Cape Town 0 86978 056 5 84–86 8th

ArgentinaArgentineGauchosare well known for using it for night orientation in the vastPampasandPatagoniaPatagonicregions. It is also of cultural significance, as it is referenced in several songs and literature, including theMartin Fierro. The Argentinian singerCharly Garciasays that he is from the southern cross in the song "No voy en tren".

article.heading: Stars
article.paragraph: Within the constellation's borders, there are 49 stars brighter than or equal toapparent magnitude6.5.efnObjects of magnitude 6.5 are among the faintest visible to the unaided eye in suburban-rural transition night skies.{{cite web|urlThe four main stars that form the asterism are Alpha, Beta, Gamma, and Delta Crucis. Also known as Acrux,Alpha Crucisis a triple star 321 light-years from Earth. Blue-tinged and magnitude 0.8 to the unaided eye, it has two close components of magnitude 1.3 and 1.8, as well as a wide component of magnitude 5. The two close components are divisible in a small amateur telescope and the wide component is divisible in a pair of binoculars.Beta Crucis, called Mimosa, is a blue-hued giant of magnitude 1.3, 353 light-years from Earth. It is aBeta Cephei-typeCepheid variablewith a variation of less than 0.1 magnitudes.sfnRidpathTirion2001132-133Gamma Crucis, called Gacrux, is an opticaldouble star. The primary is a red-hued giant star of magnitude 1.6, 88 light-years from Earth. The secondary is of magnitude 6.5, 264 light-years from Earth.Delta Crucisis a blue-white hued star of magnitude 2.8, 364 light-years from Earth. It is the dimmest of the Southern Cross stars.sfnRidpathTirion2001132-133Like Beta it is a Beta Cepheid.

There are several dimmer stars within the borders of Crux.Epsilon Crucisis an orange-hued giant star of magnitude 3.6, 228 light-years from Earth.Iota Crucisis abinary star125 light-years from Earth. The primary is an orange-hued giant of magnitude 4.6 and the secondary is of magnitude 9.5.Mu Crucisis a double star where the unrelated components are about 370 light-years from Earth. The primary is a blue-white hued star of magnitude 4.0 and the secondary is a blue-white hued star of magnitude 5.1. Mu Crucis is divisible in small amateur telescopes or large binoculars.sfnRidpathTirion2001132-133

15 of the 23 brightest stars are blue-white B-type stars.Of the five main cross stars,Delta Crucisand probablyAlpha CrucisAcruxandBeta CrucisMimosaare co-moving B-type members of theScorpiusCentaurus Association, the neareststellar associationOB associationto theSun.cite journalThe Nearest OB Association: Scorpius-Centaurus (Sco OB2)Preibisch, T., Mamajek, E.2008Handbook of Star-Forming Regions202008hsf2.book..235P0809.0407citationRizzutoAaronIrelandMichaelRobertsonJ. J., de Zeeuw, P. T., & Lub, J.Physical Parameters of Stars in the Scorpio-Centaurus OB Association[[Astronomy & Astrophysics]]2163198944–61cite journal2002AJ....124.1670M10.1086/341952Mamajek, E.E.; Meyer, M.R.; Liebert, J.Post-T Tauri Stars in the Nearest OB Association[[Astronomical Journal]]124320021670–1694astro-ph/0205417Other members include the blue-white starsZeta CrucisZeta,Lambda CrucisLambda,Mu1 CrucisMu1andMu2 CrucisMu2.cite journalA Hipparcos Census of Nearby OB Associationsde Zeeuw, P.T.; Hoogerwerf, R.; de Bruijne, J.H.J.; Brown, A.G.A.; Blaauw, A.1999Astronomical Journal1171354–991999AJ....117..354D10.1086/300682astro-ph/9809227http://iopscience.iop.org/1538-3881/117/1/354/fulltext/
Lambda CrucisandTheta2 CrucisTheta2Crucisare also Beta Cepheid stars.

Crux boasts four Cepheid variables that reach naked eye visibility.BG Crucisranges from magnitude 5.34 to 5.58 over 3.3428 days,cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?viewBG CrucisWatson, Christopher4 January 2010AAVSO WebsiteAmerican Association of Variable Star Observers12 March 2014T Crucisranges from 6.32 to 6.83 over 6.73331 days,cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?viewT CrucisWatson, Christopher4 January 2010AAVSO WebsiteAmerican Association of Variable Star Observers12 March 2014S Crucisranges from 6.22 to 6.92 over 4.68997 days,cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?viewS CrucisWatson, Christopher4 January 2010AAVSO WebsiteAmerican Association of Variable Star Observers12 March 2014andR Crucisranges from 6.4 to 7.23 over 5.82575 days.cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?viewR CrucisWatson, Christopher4 January 2010AAVSO WebsiteAmerican Association of Variable Star Observers12 March 2014BH Crucis, also known as Welch's Red Variable, is aMira variablethat ranges from magnitude 6.6 to 9.8 over 530 days.cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?viewBH CrucisOtero, Sebastian6 January 2011AAVSO WebsiteAmerican Association of Variable Star Observers23 June 2014Discovered in October 1969, it has become redder and brighter (mean magnitude changing from 8.047 to 7.762) and its period lengthened by 25% in the first thirty years since its discovery.cite journal2009JAVSO..37...87WJ. Am. Assoc. Variable star obs.3787–952009BH Crucis : Period, Magnitude, and Color ChangesWalker, W.S.G.
The starHD 106906has been found to have a planetHD 106906 bthat has a larger orbit than any otherexoplanetdiscovered to date.
article.heading: Deep-sky objects
article.paragraph: File:Southern Cross and Coalsack Dark Nebula.jpgthumbSouthern Cross and Coalsack NebulaTheCoalsack Nebulais the most prominentdark nebulain the skies, easily visible to the naked eye as a prominent dark patch in the southern Milky Way. It is large, five degrees by seven degrees, and is 600 light-years from Earth. Not all of the nebula is in the borders of Crux; some of it is technically inMuscaandCentaurus.sfnRidpathTirion2001132-133

Theopen clusterNGC 4755, better known as theJewel Box (star cluster)Jewel Boxor Kappa Crucis Cluster, has an overall magnitude of 4.2to the naked eye it appears to be a fuzzy starsfnRidpathTirion2001132-133and is about 7600 light-years from Earth.sfnLevy200587The cluster was given its name byJohn Herschel.sfnRidpathTirion2001132-133About seven million years old, an age that makes it one of the youngest open clusters in the Milky Way, it appears to have the shape of a letter A. The Jewel Box Clusters is a Shapley class g and Trumpler class I 3 r cluster; it is a very rich, centrally-concentrated cluster detached from the surrounding star field. It has more than 100 stars that range significantly in brightness.sfnLevy200587The brightest stars are mostlyblue supergiants, though the cluster contains a few brightred supergiants.Kappa Crucisis a true member of the cluster that bears its name, and is one of the brighter stars at magnitude 5.9.sfnRidpathTirion2001132-133
article.heading: Cultural significance
article.paragraph: The most prominent feature of Crux is the distinctive asterism known as the Southern Cross. It has great significance in the cultures of the southern hemisphere, particularly of New Zealand, and Australia, whose pioneers were colloquially referred to as sons and daughters of the Southern Cross.http://www.smh.com.au/national/sons-and-daughters-of-the-southern-cross-20091009-gqub.html
article.heading: Flags and symbols
article.paragraph: mainFlags depicting the Southern CrossImage:Southern cross appearing on a number of flags.PNGthumb250pxCrux, appearing on a number of flags and insigniaBeginning in the colonial age, Crux became used as a national symbol by several southern nations. The brightest stars of Crux appear on the flags offlag of AustraliaAustralia,flag of BrazilBrazil,flag of New ZealandNew Zealand,Papua New GuineaandSamoa. They also appear on the flags of theflag of VictoriaAustralian state of Victoria, theflag of Australian Capital TerritoryAustralian Capital Territory, theflag of Northern TerritoryNorthern Territory, as well as the flag ofMagallanes Region of Chile, the flag ofLondrina(Brazil) and severalArgentinaArgentineprovincial flags and emblems (for example,Tierra del Fuego Province (Argentina)Tierra del FuegoandSanta Cruz Province (Argentina)Santa Cruz). The flag of theMercosurtrading zone displays the four brightest stars. Crux also appears on theCoat of arms of BrazilBrazilian coat of armsand, as of July 2015,Brazilian passportBrazilian Passports.

In Australia, the Southern Cross played a crucial role as symbol of theEureka Stockade. In the Eureka Oath fromPeter Lalor's famous speech in 1854 under theEureka Flaghe proclaimed "We swear by the Southern Cross to stand truly by each other and fight to defend our rights and liberties."citation neededDecember 2014Of the Australian national flag, the Australian poetBanjo Patersonwrote in 1893:citation neededDecember 2014The English flag may flutter and wave,
where the world wide oceans toss,
but the flag the Australian dies to save,
is the flag of the Southern Cross.''citation neededDecember 2014The Southern Cross was written into the lyrics of "Advance Australia Fair" in 1901: "Beneath our radiant Southern Cross"; the song was adopted as the Australian National Anthem in 1984. The victory song of the Australian national cricket team is entitled "Under the Southern Cross I Stand".

The Southern Cross was included in the lyrics of theBrazilian National Anthem(1909): "A imagem do Cruzeiro resplandece" ("the image of the Cross shines"). The five stars are also in the logo of the Brazilian football teamCruzeiro Esporte Clubeand in theBrazilian coat of arms, and has even been featured as name of currency (theBrazilian cruzeirocruzeirofrom 1942 to 1986 and again from 1990 to 1994). The constellation is displayed in all coins of the current series of theBrazilian real.
InO Sweet Saint Martin's Land, the lyrics for the Southern Cross areThy Southern Cross the night.

A stylized version of Crux appears on the AustralianEureka Flag. The constellation was also used on the dark blue, shield-like patch worn by personnel of the U.S. Army'sAmerical Division, which was organized in the Southern Hemisphere, on the island ofNew Caledonia, and also the blue diamond of the1st Marine Division (United States)U.S. 1st Marine Division, which fought on the Southern Hemisphere islands ofGuadalcanalandNew Britain.
article.heading: In non-Western astronomy
article.paragraph: InAustralian Aboriginal astronomy, Crux and theCoalsackmark the head of the 'Emu in the Sky' in severalAboriginal cultures, while Crux itself is said to be apossumsitting in a tree and a representation of the sky deity Mirrabooka.Citation neededFebruary 2010Two Pacific constellations also includedGamma Centauri.Torres Strait Islandersin modern-day Australia saw Gamma Centauri as the handle and the four stars as thetridentofTagai's Fishing Spear. TheAranda peopleof central Australia saw the four Cross stars as the talon of aneagleand Gamma Centauri as its leg.sfnStaal1988249

In ancientJyotishaHindu astrology, the modern Crux is referred to asTrishanku.Cite webCrux - TrishankuSpace Yuga2010-02-10http://spaceyuga.com/crux-constellation-hindu-mythological-name-trishanku/2011-06-15

Various peoples in theEast Indiesand Brazil viewed the four main stars as the body of aray (fish)ray.sfnStaal1988249In both Indonesia and Malaysia, it is known asBintang PariandBuruj Parirespectively ("ray stars")

TheJavanese peopleof Indonesia called this constellationGubug pncng("raking hut") orlumbung("the granary"), because the shape of the constellation was like araking hut.cite journalDaldjoeniN.1984Pranatamangsa, the javanese agricultural calendar – Its bioclimatological and sociocultural function in developing rural life.http://www.springerlink.com/content/vru6945817245389/The Environmentalist415–1810.1007/BF01907286

TheMori languageMoriname for the Southern Cross isTe Punga("theanchor"). It is thought of as the anchor of Tama-rereti'swaka (canoe)waka(theMilky Way), while the Pointers are its rope.cite webhttp://www.maoridictionary.co.nz/index.cfm?wordIDMāori Dictionary; Waka o Tama-rereti, Te4 February 2013InTongait is known asToloa("duck"); it is depicted as a duck flying south, with one of his wings (Delta CrucisCrucis) wounded becauseOngo tangata("two men",CentauriandCentauri) threw a stone at it. The Coalsack is known asHumu(the "triggerfish"), because of its shape.sfnVelt1990In Samoa the constellation is calledSumu("triggerfish") because of its rhomboid shape, while and Centauri are calledLuatagata(Two Men), just as they are in Tonga. The peoples of theSolomon Islandssaw several figures in the Southern Cross. These included a knee protector and a net used to catchPalolo worms. Neighboring peoples in theMarshall Islandssaw these stars as a fish.sfnStaal1988249

InMapudungun, the language of PatagonianMapuches, the name of the Southern Cross isMelipal, which means "four stars". InQuechua languagesQuechua, the language of theIncacivilization, Crux is known as "Chakana", which means literally "stair" (chaka, bridge, link;hanan, high, above), but carries a deep symbolism within Quechua mysticism.cite webhttp://www.ancientworlds.net/aw/Article/941062Chakana: Inca Cross23 June 20079 July 2012Acrux and Mimosa make up one foot of the Great Rhea, a constellation encompassingCentaurusandCircinusalong with the two bright stars. The Great Rhea was a constellation of theBororo peopleof Brazil. TheMocov peopleof Argentina also saw arhea (bird)rheaincluding the stars of Crux. Their rhea is attacked by two dogs, represented by bright stars in Centaurus and Circinus. The dogs' heads are marked byAlpha CentauriAlphaandBeta Centauri. The rhea's body is marked by the four main stars of Crux, while its head isGamma Centauriand its feet are the bright stars ofMusca.sfnStaal1988251TheBakairi peopleof Brazil had a sprawling constellation representing a bird snare. It included the bright stars of Crux, the southern part of Centaurus, Circinus, at least one star inLupus (constellation)Lupus, the bright stars of Musca,Beta ChamaeleonisBetaandDelta Chamaeleonis,Volans, and Mensa.sfnStaal1988250TheKalapalo peopleofMato Grossostate in Brazil saw the stars of Crux asAganagiangry bees having emerged from the Coalsack, which they saw as the beehive.cite bookBassoEllen B.In Favor of Deceit: A Study of Tricksters in an Amazonian SocietyUniversity of Arizona PressTucson, Arizona19873600816510229http://books.google.com.au/books?id

AmongTuareg peopleTuaregs, the four most visible stars of Crux are considerediggaren, i.e. fourMaerua crassifoliatrees.citation neededNovember 2011TheTswana peopleofBotswanasaw the constellation asDithutlwa, two giraffes - Acrux and Mimosa forming a male, and Gacrux and Delta Crucis forming the female.cite journalCleggAndrew1986Some Aspects of Tswana CosmologyBotswana Notes and Records1833–3740979758
article.heading: In popular culture
article.paragraph: TheArgentine Air Forceacrobatic display team is calledSouthern Cross Aerobatic SquadronCruz del Sur, the Spanish for "Southern Cross".

In theVictory At Seasuite,Richard Rodgerswrote "Beneath The Southern Cross" to depict the battleships in convoy and the loneliness of the sailors in the Southern Pacific during World War II. This tango melody is also "No Other Love Have I" in the musical "Me and Juliet" and a popular hit forPerry Comoduring the 1950s.
Cruzeiro Esporte Clube(Crux/Southern Cross Sports Club) is a first class football (soccer) club in Brazil.

Melbourne'sSouthern Cross Hotelwas built and named in 1962 and was one of the city's foremost hotels during the decade. The hotel was demolished in 2005 and replaced by the similarly named office building known asSouthern Cross Tower. There is a town in the Western Australian wheatbelt approx 300 km east of Perth calledSouthern Cross, Western AustraliaSouthern Cross. Melbourne'sSouthern Cross railway station, MelbourneSpencer Street Stationwas rebuilt and renamed "Southern Cross Station" in 2006.

The 1974 AustralianAmerica's CupChallenger was named "Southern Cross" KA 4 representing the Royal Perth Yacht Club and was defeated 4-0 sailing off Newport Rhode Island by "Courageous" US26 sailing for the New York Yacht Club. Southern Cross became the trial horse for the 1977 Australian Challenger "Australia" KA 5 representing the Sun City Yacht Club that was defeated 4-0 sailing off Newport Rhode Island by Courageous US26 sailing for the New York Yacht Club.
TheCommonwealth Bank of Australiauses a stylized image of the Southern Cross as a corporate logo.

Southern Cross (Crosby, Stills and Nash song)"Southern Cross"is also a 1982 song by the classic rock groupCrosby, Stills, Nash & YoungCrosby, Stills and Nash, written by Rick Curtis, Michael Curtis, andStephen Stills. This song was also covered byJimmy Buffettand is commonly played at his concerts.

After identifying a need for a church for Afrikaans speakers living in the Netherlands, a church was established inLeusdenand is known as Suiderkruis Kerk. (Southern Cross Church) There is a town called Suiderkruis (Southern Cross) in theWestern Capeprovince of South Africa. The opening lines of South African composerKoos du Plessis' Christmas carol, 'Somerkersfees' (Summer Christmas) are:

list.listitem: Welkom o stille nag van vrede(Welcome, o silent night of peace)
Onder die suiderkruis(Beneath the Southern Cross)

article.paragraph: Zeitgeist: the Movieclaims that the Sun can be in thevicinityof Crux: this is seen through the northern hemisphere of the earth.cite webhttp://astronomy.swin.edu.au/cosmos/C/Constellation(Table of all constellations)ConstellationSwinburne UniversityCosmos - The SAO Encyclopedia of Astronomycite webhttp://astronomy.swin.edu.au/cosmos/Z/ZodiacZodiacSwinburne UniversityCosmos - The SAO Encyclopedia of Astronomy
In the 2006 video gameAce Combat X: Skies of Deception, Crux plays a major role in the story of the game and is the name of the player's radio operator.
The 1981 Black Sabbath albumMob Rules (album)Mob Rulesfeatures the song "The Sign of the Southern Cross", whose lyrics were written by then member and vocalistRonnie James Dio.

Mark Twain's travelogueFollowing the Equatorfeatures Twain remarking on the viewing the Southern Cross for the first time, "It is ingeniously named, for it looks just as a cross would look if it looked like something else."
